data.title: Official Player Ratings
data.meta_description: The NBA 2K24 Player Ratings are the official source of truth for all news and updates regarding in-game ratings.
data.text:
The Western Conference standings are filled with plenty of drama headed into the NBA Playoffs, with teams climbing up or sliding down the rankings on what seems like a nightly basis. Thereâs a good chance the Oklahoma City Thunder, Minnesota Timberwolves, and Denver Nuggets will all finish in the top three, but itâs anyoneâs guess what seed the Los Angeles Lakers, Dallas Mavericks, and Los Angeles Clippers secure.Â

Anthony Davis is doing his best to help the Lakers lock up a Play-In spot at least, Kyrie Irvingâs helping the Mavs make a final push, and Paul George is helping the Clippers hit their stride at just the right time. All three Western Conference stars are vying for a spot in the postseason and have delivered some incredible performances as of late, resulting in an increase to their player rating.

Anthony Davis, Center-Forward, Los Angeles Lakers: 95 OVR (+1)

At the beginning of the season, Anthony Davis made it a personal goal to play all 82 games in the regular season, understanding the importance of his availability for his team. While heâs likely going to fall just short of that total, heâs played in 68 out of 73 games this season, which is the most heâs played in a single year since 2017-2018 when he played 75 games. Davis has been banged up the last two weeks, but heâs remained in the starting lineup and pushed through any pain he may be experiencing. In a recent matchup against the Milwaukee Bucks, Davis played a whopping 52 minutes in a double-overtime thriller, finishing with 34 points, 23 rebounds, 4 blocks, and a much-needed win. Davisâ commitment to his team and winning deserves more praise.

Kyrie Irving, Guard, Dallas Mavericks: 91 OVR (+1)

Kyrie Irving has been a consistent contributor for the Dallas Mavericks all season, but this is the time of year when the nine-time All-Star invariably takes his game to another level in preparation for the postseason. Over the last two weeks, Irving is averaging 25.4 points, 5.3 rebounds, 7.7 assists, and 1.7 steals, providing an all-around effort on both ends of the court. The Mavsâ offense will continue to run through Luka DonÄiÄ, but when itâs clutch time, donât be surprised if Irving gets the green light. This is an NBA champion who hit one of the coldest three-pointers in NBA history in the last few secondsÂ of Game 7 during the 2016 NBA Finalsâno one wants to be tasked with defending that guy.

Paul George, Forward, Los Angeles Clippers: 90 OVR (+1)

Paul George is a bona fide superstar, but the Clippers' trade for James Harden earlier this year forced the nine-time All-Starâand other members of the teamâto slip into the background momentarily so his new teammate could get acclimated to the lineup. Now that enough time has passed and the Clippers have built some cohesion between the new starting five, George is back to commanding the court in myriad ways. Over the last two weeks, George is averaging 26 points per game, leading the Clippers in scoring during that period, and is staying active defensively with 1.7 steals per game. A lot of focus is understandably placed on Harden and Kawhi Leonard, but George could be the primary catalyst for the Clippers in the postseason if he maintains this level of production.

As the Western and Eastern Conference standings heat up ahead of the NBA Playoffs next month, so are the candidates for several individual awards. Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and Domantas Sabonis are two of a handful of players mentioned in MVP discussions on sports talk shows, and Anthony Davis is arguably the frontrunner for the Defensive Player of the Year award. As part of our latest Player Ratings, we gave each of the aforementioned players a boost to their overall rating.Â

Shai Gilgeous-Alexander, Guard, Oklahoma City Thunder: 96 OVR (+1)

Could this be the year the MVP trophy returns to Oklahoma City? With the way Shai Gilgeous-Alexander has been playing, thereâs a good chance the budding superstar takes home the MVP hardware, making him the first Thunder player to win the prestigious award since Russell Westbrook in 2017. Despite being the second-youngest team in the league with an average age of 24.12, the Thunder are experienced well beyond their years. SGA is the teamâs driving force, effortlessly averaging 31.1 points, 5.6 rebounds, 6.5 assists, and 2.2 steals per game, which currently leads the league.Â Â

Anthony Davis, Center-Forward, Los Angeles Lakers: 94 OVR (+1)

The Lakersâ big man has always been known as a defensive enforcer, but heâs been even more menacing in the paint this season. AD is currently averaging 2.5 blocks per game; the last time he averaged at least 2.5 blocks per game was in 2018 when he finished as the league leader in blocks with 2.6 per game. While he may be the Purple and Goldâs defensive anchor, heâs also averaging the second-most points on the team with 24.9 and adding 12.3 rebounds per game. Even with LeBron James on the team, Davis is the key to the Lakers' success.

Domantas Sabonis, Center, Sacramento Kings: 90 OVR (+2)

Few players are overlooked more than Domantas Sabonis, the Sacramento Kingsâ all-around sensation. Sabonis leads the league in triple-doubles this season with a whopping 21 and counting, but for some reason heâs rarely included in discussions about the best players in the NBA. However, here at NBA 2K, we know and value the gifted 27-year-old. Not only is Sabonis leading the league in triple-doubles this season, but heâs also averaging the most rebounds in the Association with a career high of 13.4. Sabonis has suited up for all 60 Kings games this year and done his part to keep the team in playoff contention, even with his teammate DeAaron Fox missing eight games this season. Sabonis might not be the flashiest player in the league, but he does everything necessary to win, and then some.

NBA All-Star Weekend is officially upon us, with many of the NBAâs best players set to make an appearance in Indianapolis for the Rising Stars tournament, Skills Challenge, and All-Star Game. Among the long list of superstars participating in the three-day event are Stephen Curry, making his 10th All-Star appearance, Jalen Brunson, earning his first All-Star selection this year, and rookie phenom Victor Wembanyama competing in the Rising Stars tournament. Over the last two weeks, the trio of talented players have delivered standout performances, resulting in increased ratings for each of them.

Stephen Curry, Guard, Golden State Warriors: 96 OVR (+1)

Itâs been an up-and-down year for Curry and the Warriors, but at the end of the day, you can never count out the four-time NBA Champion and his supporting cast. Since the start of February, the Warriors are 6-1 and Curry appears to have found his rhythm. During the last two weeks, the two-time MVP is averaging 30.7 points, 5.3 rebounds, and 4.6 assists per game, and recently hit a game-winning shot to defeat the Phoenix Suns. Going into All-Star Weekend, Curry and the Warriors are riding a hot streak; weâll see if they can keep it going following the break.

Jalen Brunson, Guard, New York Knicks: 92 OVR (+2)

Thereâs a new king of New York, and his name is Jalen Brunson. The New York Knicks starting point guard is the heartbeat of the Eastern Conferenceâs fourth-ranked squad, and is largely responsible for the teamâs impressive 33-21 record. Since joining the team via free agency in 2022, Brunson has been on a rapid ascent to stardom, improving his points and assists per game each season. Over the last 14 days, Brunson is averaging 33 points, 4 rebounds, and 6.5 assists per game. Brunsonâs star power can no longer be overlooked, and heâs more than deserving of his first career All-Star selection.

Victor Wembanyama, Center-Forward, San Antonio Spurs: 89 OVR (+1)

On February 12, the San Antonio Spursâ phenom recorded a triple-double with 27 points, 14 rebounds, and an astonishing 10 blocks, becoming the first rookie since 1990 to achieve this marvelous feat. The rookie center-forward has not only lived up to the lofty expectations set by pundits this seasonâheâs exceeding them at a historic pace. During the last two weeks, Wembanyama has averaged 19.6 points, 9.7 rebounds, and 3.6 blocks per game. On the season, the 20-year-old French star is averaging 3.2 blocks per game, which leads the league this year. Wembanyama isnât even 50 games into his NBA career yet and heâs already rewriting the record books.
